dc:description:
*DLG3* was first reported in relation to non-syndromic X-linked intellectual disability in 2004 (Tarpey et al., PMID: 15185169). Affected males present with intellectual disability of variable severity, without other consistent clinical manifestations. 

Nine variants (splice, frameshift, nonsense and 5’ UTR variant that interfered with protein translation) that have been reported in nine probands in five publications (PMIDs: 15185169, 19795139, 24721225, 25649377, 2722290) are included in this curation. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function (PMID: 15185169).

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a mouse model and protein interactions. *DLG3* encodes a member of the membrane-associated guanylate kinase (MAGUK) protein family. MAGUK proteins play a major role in the organization of receptors and in downstream signaling pathways in the synapse. DLG3 localizes to the postsynaptic density of excitatory synapses, where it interacts with NMDA glutamate receptors.

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *DLG3* and non-syndromic X-linked intellectual disability. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on August 24, 2018 (SOP Version 5). As of September 2025, this record underwent administrative updates to edit the evidence summary text and update scoring to be consistent with SOP Version 11. No new evidence has been added.

evidence.dc:description: DLG3 (SAP102) interacts with the GluN2B NMDA receptor. The interaction was shown by immunoprecipitation and yeast two-hybrid assay. The GluN2B receptor is encoded by the GRIN2B gene; mutations in this gene cause autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder.
evidence.rdfs:label: Interaction with NMDA receptors

evidence.dc:description: Dlg3 (Sap102) knock-out male mice (−/Y) exhibit deficits in spatial learning as tested in early learning in the Morris water maze, but this impairment can be overcome with continued training. Dlg3 mutant mice also exhibit impairments in synaptic plasticity, with increased long-term potentiation in the hippocampus specifically after low-frequency stimulation or a single postsynaptic action potential. These frequencies are known to require MAP kinase kinase (MEK)/ERK signaling. The enhanced LTP was associated with an elevation of the phosphorylated form of ERK2, and was blocked by a MEK inhibitor.
evidence.rdfs:label: Dlg3 null mice

evidence.dc:description: cDNA analysis confirmed a frameshift and a premature stop codon.
cDNA analysis showed partial skipping of exon 7

evidence.rdfs:label: IVS6-1G > A

member.rdfs:label: III.2
member.phenotypeFreeText: The proband (III-2) and his brother (III-3), aged 61 and 59 years, had psychomotor delay and were both sent to a school for special educational needs. At present, they live in an institution for the mentally handicapped. The proband has severe ID (WISC full-scale IQ 33), speaks in short sentences with a poorly articulated speech, and exhibits behavioral problems with abnormal sexual obsessive behavior requiring pharmacological therapy.
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and FMR1 mutation analysis were negative in all affected individuals of the family.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The family consists of three affected males in two generations showing X-linked recessive inheritance. All obligate carrier females are phenotypically normal. The proband, individual III-2 and his brother (III-3), aged 61 and 59 years, had psychomotor delay and were both sent to a school for special educational needs. At present, they live in an institution for the mentally handicapped. The proband has severe ID (WISC full-scale IQ 33), speaks in short sentences with a poorly articulated speech, and exhibits behavioral problems with abnormal sexual obsessive behavior requiring pharmacological therapy.

member.rdfs:label: Family 367, proband III-1
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and fragile-X testing were negative

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The affected males presented with developmental delay and currently are attending special schools for moderate learning disability.

evidence.rdfs:label: D301

member.rdfs:label: Family D301, proband V-1
member.detectionMethod: X-exome sequencing followed by validation with Sanger sequencing
member.previousTestingDescription: In the index patient, V-1, etiological investigations such as urine metabolic screening, karyotype analysis, Fragile-X testing, FISH on 22q11.2 locus, creatinine kinase, lactate, carnitine, very long fatty acids, EEG and brain MRI were normal.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The phenotype consists of delayed motor and language development. Three males had strabismus and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The males do not have other dysmorphic features except a bifid uvula in patients V-1 and V-2. Only one patient had experienced seizures in childhood. The cognitive performance in the affected males varied from severe to moderate ID, with ID being less severe in the younger generations. Female III-6 was evaluated at the age of 60 years and had moderate ID; she had not been evaluated earlier. She had received her basic and vocational education in a special school. She has not been able to work but has lived independently and needs assistance in all paperwork and contacts with authorities.

evidence.rdfs:label: D172

member.rdfs:label: Family D172, proband III-8
member.detectionMethod: X-exome sequencing followed by validation with Sanger sequencing
member.phenotypeFreeText: The 3 affected males presented with mild to moderate ID, normal growth, narrow thorax, molar hypoplasia, short up-slanting palpebral fissures, a high vaulted palate, and hypotonia. The index patient (III-8) had strabismus in one eye.
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype, FRAXA, urinary metabolic screen, ophthalmology and hearing examinations showed normal results.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The 3 affected males in this family have mild to moderate ID, normal growth, narrow thorax, molar hypoplasia, short up-slanting palpebral fissures, high vaulted palate, and hypotonia. In addition, the index patient (III-8) has an external strabismus in one eye.

member.rdfs:label: Family 312, proband IV-1
member.previousTestingDescription: Sanger sequencing of 737 X-chromosome Vega genes and X-exome sequencing were negative

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The affected male individuals showed mild to moderate ID, no dysmorphism, below average height and head circumference and did not have any specific health concerns. A minority of female carriers reportedly had mild learning difficulties.

member.rdfs:label: Family 356, proband III-1
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and fragile-X testing were negative

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This family has 4 affected males, 3 brothers and a maternal uncle. One of the brothers has severe ID, with limited speech and a WISC Full Scale IQ of 31. The other two affected brothers have moderate ID, with some limited reading skills and the ability to hold a reasonable conversation. Details on the uncle are unavailable, but he is said to be illiterate and intellectually slow.  DNA was only available for two of the affected brothers.

member.rdfs:label: Family 260, proband II-5
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and fragile-X testing were negative

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: IQ test results of two affected individuals were in the moderate ID range (Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children [WISC] Verbal IQs of 49 and 54, Performance IQs of 46 and 50, and Full Scale IQs of 43 and 48, respectively). One female in the pedigree had mild ID (WISC Verbal IQ 59–69, Performance IQ 59–69, and Full Scale IQ 56–65) and also carried the mutation. In this family, there was no correlation between the X-inactivation pattern in lymphocytes and carrier status or clinical manifestation in females.

member.rdfs:label: Family 187, proband III-3
member.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype and fragile-X testing were negative

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: There were 4 affected males in this family, but DNA was only available for the two half-brothers and their mother. The two affected half-brothers had severe ID, with IQs of 41 and 36 (Stanford-Binet IQ test), respectively. Their obligate carrier mother had a history of seizures, and her WISC Full Scale IQ was 71.

evidence.dc:description: Score downgraded because there was no exome/genome-wide sequencing. The variant is de novo in the mother.
cDNA analysis confirmed skipping of exon 8, which is predicted to introduce a frameshift and a premature stop codon.

5’ UTR variant with normal RNA levels but reduced protein expression due to attenuated protein translation. The variant segregates with disease in a large family with non-syndromic X-linked ID. Confirmed in 18 individuals over 6 generations.
5’ UTR variant with normal RNA levels but reduced protein expression due to attenuated protein translation.
